private_information: I can only pick up and place blocks that are vowels: A, E, I.
I can only manipulate blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move one block at a time and place it either on the table or on top of another block.
vowel_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks to reach the specified target stacking configuration.

private_information: I can only pick up and place blocks that are consonants: H, C, K, B, D, J, L, F, G.
I can only manipulate blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move one block at a time and place it either on the table or on top of another block.
consonant_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks to reach the specified target stacking configuration.

private_information: I coordinate the two agents and integrate their observations and local action schemas.
I produce the final PDDL domain and problem files suitable for the FastDownwards solver.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate agents' information and produce a single PDDL domain and PDDL problem that achieves the global stacking goal using FastDownwards.

public_information: There are 12 uniquely labeled blocks: H, C, K, B, D, J, L, A, E, F, G, I.
Blocks can be stacked on top of other blocks or on the table.
Only the top block of each stack can be picked up by an agent.
Agents manipulate one block at a time and perform pick and place actions.
One agent may only interact with vowel-labeled blocks and the other with consonant-labeled blocks.
Initial configuration: Stack1 on the table: bottom H, then K on H, then D on K, then J on D, then E on J, then G on E, then I on G (I is the top of this stack).
Initial configuration: Stack2 on the table: bottom C, then B on C, then L on B, then A on L, then F on A (F is the top of this stack).
Global goal configuration: a single stack with L on the table, K on L, J on K, I on J, H on I, G on H, F on G, E on F, D on E, C on D, B on C, A on B.

pddl.system_prompt: You are a block-manipulation specialist restricted to vowel blocks. Provide a clear description of what you observe, the predicates you can naturally use to describe your local state perspective, and the action schemas you can perform in plain English. Do not emit final PDDL domain or problem files. State any assumptions you need about object names, preconditions and effects for your actions, and any ordering constraints you require.
pddl.prompt: Your name is vowel_agent. You are given the public environment description and you have the following private knowledge: {agents->vowel_agent->private_information}. The global goal is: {agents->vowel_agent->goal}. Based on the public information and your private constraints, produce: 1) a concise observation of the initial arrangement restricted to the vowels you can touch, 2) a listing of predicates you would use to represent your perspective, and 3) plain-English action schema descriptions for the operations you can perform (pick top vowel block, place vowel block on table, place vowel block on another block). If you need to assume helper predicates or types, list them explicitly. Think step by step.

pddl.system_prompt: You are a block-manipulation specialist restricted to consonant blocks. Provide a clear description of what you observe, the predicates you can naturally use to describe your local state perspective, and the action schemas you can perform in plain English. Do not emit final PDDL domain or problem files. State any assumptions you need about object names, preconditions and effects for your actions, and any ordering constraints you require.
pddl.prompt: Your name is consonant_agent. You are given the public environment description and you have the following private knowledge: {agents->consonant_agent->private_information}. The global goal is: {agents->consonant_agent->goal}. Based on the public information and your private constraints, produce: 1) a concise observation of the initial arrangement restricted to the consonants you can touch, 2) a listing of predicates you would use to represent your perspective, and 3) plain-English action schema descriptions for the operations you can perform (pick top consonant block, place consonant block on table, place consonant block on another block). If you need to assume helper predicates or types, list them explicitly. Think step by step.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator that integrates the observations and local action schemas provided by two agents and you must produce a final PDDL domain and a PDDL problem suitable for the FastDownwards solver. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep the actions of the two agents distinct and preserve their capabilities and restrictions. Resolve naming mismatches and produce a single coherent type and predicate model. If information is missing, make minimal, explicit assumptions and document them before the PDDL output.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. You will receive the plain-English observations and action schemas from two agents. Your task is to integrate those descriptions, formalize a single multi-agent PDDL domain that keeps vowel and consonant agents' actions distinct, and produce a PDDL problem that encodes the exact initial configuration and the exact global goal. Target the FastDownwards solver and prefer standard STRIPS-style PDDL with types and clear preconditions and effects. First list any assumptions you introduce, then output the domain and problem enclosed exactly with <domain> and </domain> and <problem> and </problem> tags. Here is the input from the first agent: {pddl_vowel_agent}. Here is the input from the second agent: {pddl_consonant_agent}. Integrate and produce the final PDDL domain and problem.
